org.epochx.epox
Class EpoxParser

java.lang.Object
  org.epochx.epox.EpoxParser

public class EpoxParser
extends java.lang.Object

This parser is for parsing valid Epox programs into a node tree. It is only able to parse those node types which are part of the standard language, or which have been added to the parser through its declareXxx methods. It is also only able to construct instances of standard nodes which require no additional arguments provided to their constructor, this excludes all nodes which can handle multiple arities, such as the SeqNFunction function. Instead, use the explicit arity versions such as Seq2Function, or provide an already constructed instance of the node to the parser through the declareFunction(String, Node) method.

Variables may be named with any String. There will be no name clash between variables and functions. There could however be a clash between variables and literals, so variable names that could be parsed as any valid literal value should be avoided.

Literals will be parsed by first matching against any user declared literals, then by attempting to parse the value as a Java primitive.

See Also:
Node

Method Detail

parse

public Node parse(java.lang.String source)
           throws MalformedProgramException
Parses an Epox program string as an executable Node tree. The given source parameter must contain a valid Epox program string, comprised only of functions, variables and literals that have been declared. The data-types of each function's inputs must correspond to valid data-types, otherwise a MalformedProgramException will be thrown.

If the source parameter is null, then null will be returned.

Parameters:
source - the program string to be parsed as an Epox program.
Returns:
a Node which is the root of a tree which is equivalent to the provided source string. A null value will be returned if the source parameter is null.
Throws:
MalformedProgramException - if the given string does not represent a valid Epox program.

parseLiteral

protected Literal parseLiteral(java.lang.String literalStr)
Parses the given string as the value of a literal. Any user declared literals are checked first, if any match, then a new Literal node is constructed with the provided Object as the value. If no match is made then an attempt will be made to parse the string as one of the following types: (boolean, String, char, int, long, double, float), which will become the value of a newly constructed Literal, which will be returned. If parsing fails, then null will be returned.

Parameters:
literalStr - the string to be parsed as some type of Literal
Returns:
a new Literal instance with a value as parsed, or null if the string was unable to be parsed.

parseNumericLiteral

protected Literal parseNumericLiteral(java.lang.String numericStr)
Attempts to parse the given string as a number, and wraps it in a new Literal instance that is returned. If unable to parse the given string as a number, then this method will return null.

The string will be parsed as follows:

  • If the string contains a numeric value (with or without decimal) followed by a 'd' or 'D' character, then the literal will have a Double value.
  • If the string contains a numeric value (with or without decimal) followed by an 'f' or 'F' character, then the literal will have a Float value.
  • If the string contains a numeric value followed by an 'l' or 'L' character, or if the value is an integer value out of range of the Java int type, then the literal will have a Long value.
  • If the string contains an integer value in range of the Java int type then the literal will have an Integer value.

Parameters:
numericStr - a string containing a numeric value to be parsed as a Literal.
Returns:
a new Literal with a numeric value. Or null if the given numericStr could not be parsed as a numeric value.

declareLiteral

public void declareLiteral(java.lang.String literalStr,
                           java.lang.Object literalValue)
Declares a new literal that may be parsed as the given literal value. The literalStr should not match the name of any declared variables. When parsing an Epox program, the given string found as a terminal, will be parsed as a new Literal instance of the given value. The new literal's value will be a shallow copy of the given Object. If a literal with an equal literalStr has previously been declared, then it will be overwritten.

Parameters:
literalStr - the string representation that if matched against a terminal in an Epox program undergoing parsing, will be constructed as a Literal of the given Object value.
literalValue - the Object value to assign a new Literal that matches the given literalStr.

undeclareLiteral

public java.lang.Object undeclareLiteral(java.lang.String literalStr)
Removes the given literalStr from those that can be parsed. Any future terminals that match the given literalStr will no longer be parsed as a new Literal.

Parameters:
literalStr - the literal string that should no longer be parsed as a Literal.
Returns:
the previously declared literal value that was removed, or null if nothing was removed.

declareFunction

public void declareFunction(java.lang.String name,
                            java.lang.Class<? extends Node> functionClass)
Declares a new function that can be constructed when a function of the given name is parsed. During parsing if a function is encountered with an identifier that matches the provided name parameter, then a new instance of the given Node class is constructed. Note that any functions provided as nodes to the declareFunction(String, Node) method, will be constructed in preference to those declared through a call to this method. Declaring a new function using this method with a name that is equal to any previously declared functions, will replace the existing function - this applies to the standard Epox functions too, which may be replaced through this method.

Parameters:
name - the identifier to match when parsing the provided function.
functionClass - a Class from which a new node will be constructed, upon parsing of an Epox function with the given name.

declareFunction

public void declareFunction(java.lang.String name,
                            Node functionNode)
Declares a new function that can be constructed when a function of the given name is parsed. During parsing if a function is encountered with an identifier that matches the provided name parameter, then a new instance of the given Node is constructed. Note that functions provided through this method will be constructed in preference to those declared through a call to the declareFunction(String, Class) method. Declaring a new function using this method with a name that is equal to any previously declared functions, will replace the existing function. The standard Epox functions will also be overridden, since functions declared through this method are given preference.

Parameters:
name - the identifier to match when parsing the provided function.
functionNode - a Node from which a new instance will be constructed upon parsing of an Epox function with the given name.

undeclareFunction

public void undeclareFunction(java.lang.String name)
Removes any functions of the given name from those that can parsed. This includes those functions declared through either of the declareFunction methods, or the standard Epox functions.

Parameters:
name - the identifier of the function that should no longer be parsed.

declareVariables

public void declareVariables(java.util.List<Variable> variables)
Declares the given variables, so that any terminals that match the identifiers of the given variables will be parsed as such.

Parameters:
variables - the variables that should be declared.

declareVariable

public void declareVariable(Variable variable)
Declares the given variable, so that any terminals that match the given variable's identifier will be parsed as that variable.

Parameters:
variable - the variable that should be declared.

undeclareVariable

public void undeclareVariable(Variable variable)
Removes the given variable from those that are parseable. The variable's identifier will no longer be parsed as that variable.

Parameters:
variable - the variable to be undeclared.

undeclareAllVariables

public void undeclareAllVariables()
Removes all variables from those that are parseable. The parser will no longer recognise any variables.
